Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: The nun has been chosen to represent the convent and lead a prayer vigil at a major public religious event.
Story: I sat at my desk, lesson plans spread before me, the clock ticking down to the project deadline. My mentees depended on me to guide them, to share the skills they needed to succeed. I had promised them a structured session, and I could see their anxious faces in my mind, waiting for clarity and direction. Yet, as I organized my notes, the convent’s bell tolled, a reminder of my other calling. Today, I was not just a mentor—I was also a nun, chosen to lead the prayer vigil at the city’s cathedral, a rare honor and a duty to my sisters and faith. The Mother Superior’s words echoed in my heart: “You will represent us all.” I felt the weight of both expectations pressing in, the needs of my mentees and the sacred responsibility to my community. My hands trembled as I tried to focus, torn between the secular and the spiritual, between nurturing minds and uplifting souls. The minutes slipped away, and I found myself paralyzed, caught in the silent storm of conflicting loyalties, unsure which path to follow.
